posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You know those glossy, ultra-slick action movies from the mid-90s
to early 2000s where they didn't care for realistic physics or
whatever, they just wanted it to look awesome? Give me some
recommendations for those kind of movies.

Criteria - REQUIRED:
- kickass action that doesn't give two shits about being realistic
- Dark gritty cities
- Guns, LOTS of guns
- weapons that might be made of chrome
- really unique weapon, costume and set designs
- Secret organizations

NOT 100% Required
- Supernatural element and evil inhuman monsters, possibly with a conspiracy or mystery to solve
- good looking protagonist, possibly laden in something with leather
- May or may NOT have had Patrick Tatopoulos in production in some way or other
- heavy metal, hip-hop or techno soundtrack (DEFINITELY not required, but helps)
- Made before 2010 (NOT required, as several entries below will show you)

posts.name: ESSENTIALS
posts.com:
List so far

ESSENTIALS
1 - Alien series (protozoa for this kind of shit, as is the Terminator series...at least the first 3)
2 - Blade (THE codifier for everything on this series; same with the Matrix)
3 - Resident Evil film series, directed by Paul WS Anderson as well as
4 - Underworld film series
5 - Doom 2005 with The Rock and Karl Urban
6 - Ultraviolet by Kurt Wimmer with Milla Jovovich

posts.name: SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL
posts.com:
List so far

SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL

1 - Nemesis 1992 (remember when Selene in Underworld escaped the Lycans by blasting the floor into Swiss cheese? This film did it first. No joke, and it's AWESOME!)
2 - The Crow
3 - Uwe Boll's House of the Dead and Alone in the Dark (despite their reception they could when you actually watch them)
4 - Equilibrium (also directed by Kurt Wimmer)
5 - Priest 2011
6 - Hardcore Henry (minus horror element, fits the criteria above to a fucking T)
7 - I, Frankenstein (made by the guy who made Underworld and was SUPPOSED to have a crossover with it but, well, that fell through for one reason or another
8 - Hellboy and Hellboy 2: The Golden Army

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: tron

posts.name: POSSIBLY
posts.com:
List so far

POSSIBLY


1 - Van Helsing with Hugh Jackman
2 - League of Extraordinary Gentlemen with Sean Connery
3 - Aeon Flux with Charlize Theron (not sure about the cartoon)
4 - Event Horizon (also directed by Paul WS Anderson)
5 - Alien vs Predator series (also directed by Paul WS Anderson, though with the description I gave it might not be 100% correct)
6 - Queen of the Damned with Stuart Townsend and Aaliyah (very stylish but no cool gadgets)
7 - District 9 - What happens in the film is genuinely terrifying and the tech is cool, but doesn't have the color grading of what I mentioned...also none of them are found footage like District 9
8 - Legion (directed by the guy who made Priest, haven't watched it but seen some clips)
9 - Men in Black Series before International (scary shit in it, fits criteria mentioned above, but focuses more on Sci-Fi than horror honestly)
10 - Sam Raimi's Spider-Man films and Ben Affleck's Daredevil (the former has lots of cool high tech stuff, genuinely scary things, fitting for a horror director, while the latter has a hero clad in leather in a dark gritty city with a conspiracy/mystery solve, and both proudly say FUCK YOU to realistic physics or grounded action)

posts.com:
ffmpeg let's you cut/copy out a portion without encoding (though i still use audacity to preview the waveform)

ffmpeg -ss 00:02:56.843 -i "input_file.m4a" -t 24.572 -c copy "out_file.m4a"
-ss seeks to the starting time
-t is the duration to be processed
time format:
https://trac.ffmpeg.org/wiki/Seeking#Timeunitsyntax

don't use "-to", it tends to break the timing

https://archive.palanq.win/wsr/thread/1235818/#1237559

r = [cos θ, -sin θ;
sin θ, cos θ]
θ = 90°
r = [0, -1;
1, 0]

r* [1;
1] = [1*0 + 1*1;
1*-1 + 1*0]
= [1,-1]
r*[-1;
-1] = [-1*0 + -1*1;
-1*-1 + -1*0]
= [-1;
1]

our line is transformed from (1,1)->(-1,-1) to (1,-1)->(-1,1), a 90° rotation QED

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1318537
>why would locking pliers work where normal pliers failed me?
As the name suggests, they lock. You tighten the screw up over the thing you're trying to twist, unclick them, tighten the screw up a bit more, then click them on again (it will be significantly harder to do this, because to shut them you're now bending the metal cross-brace of the pliers). This makes them bite it like a motherfucker, and not let go.

You can then turn the pliers without needing to apply any force to hold them closed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1319163
it's not even that, Japanese don't do everything right-to-left at all. Even written Japanese can be done left to right if you want, and in fact, they now write words left to right when writing horizontally (you can see the difference if you look up, for example, Nintendo's 1920 factory building, whose sign says 堂天任 (dotennin) rather than 任天堂 (nintendo)). You'll frequently see graphs and charts written in a familiar format of charting time as a passage from left to right or of key names being on the left and data following in columns going right. Reading from top-right corner to bottom-left corner is a holdover in books and comics. I don't know why it's a holdover, but that's how it is.

tl;dr Japanese does what it wants and you just gotta roll with it. Eventually you stop seeing it as anything weird.

Kemono Jihen - Very nice artstyle and otherwise straightforward and heartwarming shonen action story, often leaning into the occasional genocide, monster rape and assorted silliness like "semen wrung dry by your dozens of aunts to keep your village alive"

Kitanai Kimi ga Ichiban - Lesbian schoolgirl manga quickly descends into sheer insanity and four-dimensional abuse chess, but its stereotypically "soft" yuri artsyle soldiers on.

Zekkyou Gakkyuu - Shoujo horror, and not too extreme. Has some off-screen rape and a lot of death/fates worse than death happening to cutely drawn elementary schoolers. Probably the least edgy on this list.

Reki Yomi - Cute kemonomimi sisters do revolting things. Japanese Ren and Stimpy. [spoiler]Actually really good.[/spoiler]

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

>Why would I use them over ceramic or electrolytic capacitors?

They are electrolytic capacitors.

They have better power density than other electrolytic capacitors so are smaller for same capacitance. They leak (charge) less. They resist high temperature better and have longer lifetimes.

I looked at that project. based on how rough the results are going to be, I don't see any reason for tantalum over any other capacitor. The other ones are just as likely to fail so you'll be fixing it in a few years or decades anyway. (I just had to fix a 40+ year old device because one cap failed. The other caps are fine.)

ps I just looked at your pic. It even says "tantalum electrolyte"

void getIndex(int number){

int numList[] =...

for(int i = 0; i < (sizeof(numList)/sizeof(int)); i++){
if(numList[i] == number){ cout << "number " << number << " found at position " << i << "!\n";}
}
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318865
>she barely gets above 6 GB at the moment
The "empty" RAM becomes disk cache, which makes the computer feel fast. Task manager is very particular in the language it uses: it doesn't say "free" or "unused", it says "available". If the RAM is needed for anonymous pages, then fine, it gets zeroed and handed to a process. But if the page that held winword.exe survives not being overwritten the whole time Word was closed, then when you reopen Word you get it for free: no disk activity required, because it's still in RAM from last time.

You don't want to skimp on RAM, particularly as you seem to have an eight-year replacement cycle. It's what makes the difference between the computer being "okay" and being "nice".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318865
>laptops with out an ethernet port (which she absolutely doesn't want to compromise on)
>She absolutely doesn't want a docking station or an USB3 dock
No offence, but it sounds like you're being asked to provide "a really fast horse".

They don't make laptops with ethernet ports, because of USB3 dongles* and gigabit wifi. They don't make laptops with tons of ports because USB3 is so fast you can just use a hub and get 5-8 full-speed ports. You have to plug a charging cable in anyway, so there's zero extra hassle if it's a thunderbolt/USB4 cable that's charging your laptop and also hooking it to a monitor, mouse, keyboard and ethernet, even an eGPU.

Given the size of your premises, you might be better off spending $100 less on a laptop, and $100 on a Ubiquiti AP so everyone can have .5GB wifi. (or $200 for
1GB wifi).

I think it's worth exploring just how much computers have changed since 2015, and asking if, instead of making a problem faster, it might be possible to remove it altogether.

* you have to plug the ethernet cable in anyway, so just leave a USB dongle on the end of the cable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1318900
>the CPU is sperging out now and then and running at 100%, effectively freezing the whole machine for seconds to a minute.
Clean the radiator. There's two causes that account for 95-99% of this behaviour:
- storage device going nonresponsive: this looks like 100% CPU usage because the OS is spinning inside the kernel, waiting for some memory page it needs to become available
- overheating: this looks like 100% CPU usage because the OS is using 100% of whatever CPU cycles are actually available. If the overheating is particularly bad, the CPU will actually stop completely, which to the OS looks like whatever process was on the CPU used 100% of it the whole time it was down.

So if you can rule out the storage device going catatonic, the next step is to take the fan off the heatsink and clean all the shit off the backside of the radiator. If you're feeling keen, you can also replace the thermal paste and thermal pads, but if you can find a way to get the fan shroud off and leave the heatsink on, then you won't need to.
